image.altText: A man and a woman smile as they hold an infant.

items.synopsis: Matthew Cox has been charged with murder after police found the bodies of his wife and baby girl.

title.children: Parents of Queensland man accused of killing his wife and 11-week-old daughter in 'state of shock'

image.altText: An Asian woman standing behind a coffee machine.

items.synopsis: Cafes and restaurants saw a boom of big-spending customers after the pandemic. Now, as cost-of-living pressures bite households and the cost of doing business grows, some in the hospitality industry are struggling to stay afloat.

title.children: A perfect storm is brewing at Lillian's cafe: Rising costs and fewer customers coming through the door

image.altText: Former President Donald Trump waves after announcing he is running for president for the third time.

items.synopsis: Prosecutors allege two aides schemed with Donald Trump to try to delete Mar-a-Lago surveillance video sought by investigators.

title.children: Donald Trump and aides plead not guilty to concealing classified documents

image.altText: Dale Josiah sits on a hospital bed

items.synopsis: Dale Josiah and his family moved eight hours' drive from their community for vital health treatment. He's "overwhelmed" a new facility could see the family return home for good.

title.children: Dialysis keeps Dale alive, but his community makes life worth living. Soon, he could have both

image.altText: Older man in blue shirt.

items.synopsis: With the country gripped by the mystery surrounding the death of three elderly Victorians from suspected death cap mushroom poisoning, Simon Claringbold knows better than most how dangerous the fungus can be.

title.children: 'I thought it was the end': Death cap mushroom survivor recounts brush with death

image.altText: Man in white shirt standing behind a podium waves to the camera

items.synopsis: This parliamentary week involved a pitched battle over how many pages are in the Uluru Statement and a bold Coalition stand against cheaper drugs. But no one could stay grumpy when Kevin Rudd's official portrait was unveiled, writes Annabel Crabb.

title.children: It was a tricky week in parliament for Anthony Albanese. Then Kevin Rudd made a comeback

image.altText: Grace Corvo works in a kitchen.

items.synopsis: Grace makes and delivers homemade lasagne to supplement her main source of income. She's just one of nearly 200,000 young Australians working more than one job to make ends meet.

title.children: 'Young people are hustlers': Gen Z 'willing to do what they need to' to make ends meet

image.altText: A husband and wife clutching a letter outside a home.

items.synopsis: Brisbane City Council says it's sorry for sending cryptic letters that led home owners to mistakenly believe their houses would be bulldozed to make way for parks.

title.children: Brisbane council apologises after 'ambiguous' letters leave home owners fearing they will be forced to sell

image.altText: The ship HMAS Brisbane docked at a fleet base in Sydney.

items.synopsis: Visiting warships from India, Japan and the United States will be welcomed into Sydney Harbour on Friday as the annual "Exercise Malabar" military drills are hosted by Australia for the first time.

title.children: Joint naval drills between US, Australia, India and Japan 'more important than ever'

image.altText: Journalist Cheng Lei is seen smiling while seated with the Shanghai waterfront in the background.

items.synopsis: Australian journalist Cheng Lei, who was arrested and jailed in China three years ago, has released her first public statement describing the harsh conditions of her imprisonment and how much she misses Australia.

title.children: Ten hours of sunlight per year: Australian Cheng Lei's first message from Chinese prison

image.altText: A burning building next to palm trees blowing in strong wind

items.synopsis: The deaths were reported by Maui County as the devastating wildfire continues to rip through the island.

title.children: 'It's like an apocalypse': At least 36 killed, thousands displaced in Hawaii's Lahaina wildfires

image.altText: Jacinta Price is on the left speaking in the red Senate chamber. On the right is Anthony Albanese speaking in the green house

items.synopsis: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese and Shadow Minister for Indigenous Australians Jacinta Price have been arguing about the length of the Uluru Statement from the Heart. Who is correct?

title.children: Anthony Albanese says the Uluru Statement is one page, Jacinta Price says it's 26. Who is correct?

image.altText: An island-like complex with red buildings and trees surrounded by water is seen from above, a white strip connecting to land

items.synopsis: The city of Bangkok is sinking, with coastal residents rebuilding their homes on stilts and erecting giant walls to protect sacred buildings from being swallowed by the sea.

title.children: 'This not fortune-telling, this is science': Climate change experts sound the alarm on the sinking city of Bangkok

image.altText: A soccer team wearing yellow and green uniforms stand in two rows for a photo before a match

items.synopsis: A Queensland program believed to be one of the oldest female football academies in the world may well be the secret to the Australian team's success.

title.children: 'Something in the water': Why almost half of the Matildas are from Queensland

image.altText: A local resident stands next to a museum building, heavily damaged by a Russian missile strike.

items.synopsis: Ukrainian authorities order the evacuation of nearly 12,000 civilians from 37 towns and villages in the eastern Kharkiv region, where Russian forces are reportedly making a concerted effort to punch through the front line.

title.children: Ukraine orders 12,000 civilians to leave eastern Kharkiv region amid Russian forces' push towards Kupiansk

image.altText: Lowe gestures with one hand, sitting at a table in suit and tie, a news camera visible behind him.

items.synopsis: Philip Lowe will face the house economics committee hearing as RBA governor for the final time this morning. Meanwhile US inflation continues to cool, increasing the chance the Federal Reserve will leave rates on hold at its next meeting. Follow live.

title.children: Outgoing RBA boss Philip Lowe to face final parliamentary grilling, US inflation cools

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Here's a very quick whip-around of some other results that have come out this morning: Furniture retailer Nick Scali has posted a record net profit of $101.1 million, attributing growth to a fall in shipping delays after the pandemic, resulting in more sales. Baby Bunting's profit took a hit, falling to $14.5 million — down 51% from the previous financial year. Acting CEO Darin Hoekman said the fall was due to parents pulling back on spending due to cost-of-living pressures. Newcrest Mining reported a $US778 million profit in FY23.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Nick Scali posts record profit, Baby Bunting earnings slide

children.content: Here's a very quick whip-around of some other results that have come out this morning:
Furniture retailer
Nick Scali
has posted a record net profit of $101.1 million, attributing growth to a fall in shipping delays after the pandemic, resulting in more sales.
Baby Bunting's

profit took a hit, falling to $14.5 million — down 51% from the previous financial year. Acting CEO Darin Hoekman said the fall was due to parents pulling back on spending due to cost-of-living pressures.
Newcrest Mining
reported a $US778 million profit in FY23.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: REA Group, the company behind property advertising site realestate.com.au, has posted its earnings for the most recent financial year, recording a net profit of $372 million — down 9% on the last financial year's figure. The Group told the ASX it delivered a "resilient result in challenging market conditions", which included "significantly lower" listings compared to FY22. CEO Owen Wilson said the company's revenue growth was driven by its REA India division, but flagged there may be higher losses in the future. "The fundamentals of the Australian property market remain healthy," he said. "We are continuing to see strong demand and a return to price growth, and this is converting to a more attractive market for sellers. "We believe the stabilisation of interest rates is within sight and we expect this will lead to an increase in market activity. "[REA Group] are focused on delivering products that provide the greatest value to customers and enhance the experience of our audience, and we see significant opportunities in the year ahead." REA Group will cut its full-year dividends by 4% to $1.58.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: REA Group reports $372 million profit after 'challenging market conditions'

children.content: REA Group, the company behind property advertising site realestate.com.au, has posted its earnings for the most recent financial year,
recording a net profit of $372 million
— down 9% on the last financial year's figure.
The Group told the ASX it delivered a
"resilient result in challenging market conditions"
, which included "significantly lower" listings compared to FY22.
CEO Owen Wilson said the company's revenue growth was driven by its REA India division, but
flagged there may be higher losses in the future
"The fundamentals of the Australian property market remain healthy," he said.
"We are continuing to see strong demand and a return to price growth, and this is
converting to a more attractive market for sellers
"We believe the
stabilisation of interest rates is within sight
and we expect this will
lead to an increase in market activity
"[REA Group] are focused on delivering products that provide the greatest value to customers and enhance the experience of our audience, and we see significant opportunities in the year ahead."
REA Group will cut its full-year dividends by 4% to $1.58.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The financial regulator has launched civil proceedings against Active Super over claims it misled customers by claiming it was an "ethical and responsible superannuation fund". On its website, Active Super claimed not to invest in industries that threatened the environment and the community — meaning it didn't invest funds in tobacco manufacturing, gambling, coal mining and oil tar sands. The super fund also said it added Russia to its list of excluded countries after it illegally invaded Ukraine last year. But ASIC alleges Active Super "exposed its members to investments it claimed to restrict or eliminate", claiming it had 28 holdings, directly or indirectly, that contradicted its ethical stance, between February 1, 2021 and June 30, 2023. Those holdings included: Gambling : Skycity Entertainment Group Limited, PointsBet Holdings Limited, The Star Entertainment Group Limited, The Lottery Corporation Limited and Tabcorp Holdings Limited; Tobacco : Amcor PLC; Russian entities : Gazprom PJSC and Rosneft Oil Company; Oil Tar Sands : ConocoPhillips; Coal Mining : Coronado Global Resources Inc., New Hope Corporation Limited and Whitehaven Coal Limited. ASIC also alleges Active Super claimed it would stop investing in Russian companies from May 2022, but holdings in Russian securities remained in place as of the end of June 2023. "There is much competition among super funds for new members, and we know that funds seek to attract members with promises their investments will not be exposed to certain industries," said Sarah Court, ASIC's Deputy Chair. "When making these claims super funds must have evidence to back their claims and ensure they are not promising exclusions that they cannot guarantee." It's the third greenwashing civil penalty ASIC has launched, after taking action against Mercer Super and Vanguard. A spokesperson for Active Super said the fund has cooperated with ASIC's investigation, and " welcomes increased scrutiny on ESG disclosure standards as being good for members, the super industry and the community". "As the matter is before the courts we are unable to comment further," the spokesperson said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASIC takes Active Super to court for falsely claiming it was an 'ethical' superannuation fund

children.content: The financial regulator has launched civil proceedings against
Active Super
over claims it misled customers by claiming it was an "ethical and responsible superannuation fund".
On its website,
Active Super claimed not to invest in industries that threatened the environment and the community
— meaning it didn't invest funds in tobacco manufacturing, gambling, coal mining and oil tar sands.
The super fund also said it added Russia to its list of excluded countries after it illegally invaded Ukraine last year.
But ASIC alleges Active Super
"exposed its members to investments it claimed to restrict or eliminate"
, claiming it had 28 holdings, directly or indirectly, that contradicted its ethical stance, between February 1, 2021 and June 30, 2023.
Those holdings included:
Gambling
: Skycity Entertainment Group Limited, PointsBet Holdings Limited, The Star Entertainment Group Limited, The Lottery Corporation Limited and Tabcorp Holdings Limited;
Tobacco
: Amcor PLC;
Russian entities
: Gazprom PJSC and Rosneft Oil Company;
Oil Tar Sands
: ConocoPhillips;
Coal Mining
: Coronado Global Resources Inc., New Hope Corporation Limited and Whitehaven Coal Limited.
ASIC also alleges Active Super claimed it would stop investing in Russian companies from May 2022, but holdings in Russian securities remained in place as of the end of June 2023.

"There is much competition among super funds for new members, and we know that funds seek to attract members with promises their investments will not be exposed to certain industries," said Sarah Court, ASIC's Deputy Chair.
"When making these claims super funds must have evidence to back their claims and ensure they are not promising exclusions that they cannot guarantee."
It's the
third greenwashing civil penalty ASIC has launched
, after taking action against
Mercer Super
and
Vanguard
A spokesperson for Active Super said the
fund has cooperated with ASIC's investigation
, and "
welcomes increased scrutiny on ESG disclosure standards
as being good for members, the super industry and the community".
"As the matter is before the courts we are unable to comment further," the spokesperson said.

image.altText: A scuba diver examines bleached and dying corals under the water.

items.synopsis: Scientists are concerned that "extremely warm" ocean temperatures on the Great Barrier Reef are a sign of a "potentially catastrophic" coral bleaching event to come.

title.children: Marine heatwave in Great Barrier Reef sparks fear of 'potentially catastrophic' coral bleaching event

image.altText: A Pacific Islander worker picking raspberries.

items.synopsis: Changes to the Pacific Islander labour scheme mean workers must be guaranteed a minimum of 30 hours of work each week, but the horticulture industry says the seasonal nature of the work and weather events make that unworkable.

title.children: Growers warn 'unworkable' Pacific Islander worker changes lack critical flexibility required for horticulture

image.altText: Quiz thumbnail

items.synopsis: Have you been paying attention this week? Time to find out.

title.children: Weekly news quiz: Matildas score game with France and MTV video music award nominees make history

image.altText: A woman in a teal jersey carefully balances a soccer ball on her head on a soccer pitch.

items.synopsis: Find out how to watch the Sam Kerr-captained team battle it out for a place in the FIFA Women's World Cup semifinals.

title.children: When do the Matildas play next, and what time? Everything you need to know about their match against France

image.altText: A woman wearing a grey jacket and white hat holds a trophy and yells

items.synopsis: The only coach to win back-to-back Women's World Cup titles, former USA boss Jill Ellis, says the Matildas can go all the way.

title.children: Can the Matildas win the World Cup? We asked someone who won it twice

image.altText: A marketing photo of different brightly-coloured watches.

items.synopsis: Law enforcement raid Swatch stores throughout Malaysia's capital as part of the nation's latest crackdown on what it called "LGBTQ elements" of society.

title.children: Wearing a rainbow Swatch watch could now see you jailed for three years in Malaysia

image.altText: Exterior gate at Risdon prison, Tasmania.

items.synopsis: The number of meetings potentially compromised by the covert police surveillance of a room at Tasmania's Risdon Prison could number in the hundreds, it has been revealed — with the matter described as a "massive breach of privacy" which demands a "comprehensive review".

title.children: Police live-streamed potentially hundreds of legally privileged lawyer-prisoner conversations in bugged room

image.altText: Three people sit around a desk in discussion, in a room with official-looking posters on the wall behind them.

items.synopsis: Federal and territory governments have been warned that a shortfall in interpreters is affecting access to justice for Aboriginal people. Yet the problem's only getting worse.

title.children: This lawyer's client could end up in prison — because he doesn't speak English

image.altText: Jackie Molea- Chow

items.synopsis: The Pacific Games are coming to Solomon Islands. But with hospitals, roads, and other basic infrastructure in a state of disrepair, many are asking a simple question: Is it a good investment?

title.children: They're the Pacific's 'mini Olympics'. But with a stadium gifted by China and millions invested, not everyone wants them

image.altText: Peter Dutton sits in the House of Representatives

items.synopsis: Crazy brave, or just crazy? If, as seems likely, the opposition embraces nuclear power in its 2025 election policy, it will be taking a huge political gamble, writes Michelle Grattan.

title.children: Will Australians embrace nuclear? The Coalition might take the gamble

image.altText: A man with long white hair and a woman with long brown hair stand next to each other, looking serious.

items.synopsis: We Mavericks were shocked to find someone had downloaded their album, slowed each song down and re-uploaded it to streaming services under another name. They say other artists are at risk of this new type of copyright theft.

title.children: Aussie band stunned to hear their song on Spotify by a performer who doesn't exist

image.altText: Water rushing through a broken wall down into a green valley

items.synopsis: Authorities were previously planning to blow up a part of the dam to prevent communities downstream from being inundated.

title.children: Dam bursts in Norway after days of heavy rain and flooding from Storm Hans

image.altText: A man speaks to the media outside court.

items.synopsis: The husband of an SA mum killed by a drunk P-plater who was speeding, on his phone, and on the wrong side of the road, tells an Adelaide court of the moments after the crash when he tried to save his wife.

title.children: Victim's husband slams killer driver's 'pathetic and cowardly' act after fatal crash

image.altText: An oil painting of Kevin Rudd in his Queensland home, a cat wanders on the table in front of him, a wall of books behind him.

items.synopsis: Kevin Rudd is now a permanent presence within the halls of Parliament House, with his official portrait joining those of other former PMs 10 years after he quit parliament.

title.children: Kevin Rudd re-enters parliament — as a painting
